I needed my ID to move around without getting caught. and I took these 12 photos with me in case I wanted to look back and reminisce. I wrote on the back of them so as not to forget.Ji Sung-ho, 35, from Hoeryong, near the border with China. He left North Korea in 2006 with a pair of wooden crutches. I lived as a child beggar in North Korea. I was stealing coals from a train when I fell off and lost my leg and my hand. I had to bring the crutches with me. If I didn't have them, I wouldn't have made it here. The state doesn't help you in North Korea, and people who need crutches make their own. Mine are therefore not factory-made, so they're not perfect and break easily. I had several pairs of crutches but they all broke, and this was the last pair. I used these crutches for 10 years, until I was 25, when I arrived in South Korea. I would steal coal from moving trains and fall off, destroying my crutches. Or I would get beaten up by the police and they'd take and then break my crutches. When they broke, I would make new ones. When I had new ones, I could go back outside.When I first arrived in South Korea I thought about throwing them out. South Korea's intelligence agency gave me a prosthetic leg. My friends said I should throw the crutches out and not think about North Korea. They said I should show Kim Jong Il I was living a new life in South Korea and throw out everything I had from the North. Some asked if I got upset when I saw my crutches. But I couldn't just throw them out. To make my crutches, my friends had given me some wood that they had bought, and someone I knew in North Korea who had carpentry skills had made them. It was my father who added the final touches. There is a lot of love from my North Korean friends and family in these crutches. So I didn't throw them out. The South Korean government gave me some new crutches because the wood from my North Korean ones is hard and painful. But I still keep them, so as not to forget those memories. Kim Ryen Hui, 48, is from Pyongyang. She says she never wanted to defect. In 2011, she says, a broker helped her go to China for treatment on her liver. But the broker tricked her, she said, and she ended up in South Korea. She is campaigning to return, which Seoul says would be against the law. I miss my parents even more than I miss my daughter. They're everything to me. For the first few years, I couldn't even breathe properly when I thought of them. My little brother lives with them in Pyongyang now. My mother can't see out of one eye. The thing I fear the most is finding out they've passed away before I have the chance to go back. My daughter and I have been writing letters and sending photos to each other. My cousin lives in China, so she's been sending them on. My daughter's name is Ri Ryon Gum. She was born on February 15, 1993. I don't want her to live out her life with me here. When she was young, she did taekwondo. She wanted to get involved in espionage operations against South Korea. She was so fearless. That's why she was doing taekwondo - to get involved in anti-South espionage. So I was really surprised to hear she became a chef. In a video of her I received, she explained why. She said that after I had left, she moved in with her father in Pyongyang and had been cooking for him. She said she decided to become a chef so she could fulfill my role at home. I was sad when I heard that.Lee Min-bok, 60, was a researcher at North Korea's Academy of Agricultural Science. He first tried to defect, unsuccessfully, in 1990. He eventually left North Korea in June 1991 and came to South Korea in 1995. His family sent him these diaries. I have a bit of an academic side. According to Kim Il Sung's teachings, people are supposed to keep diaries. Everyone in North Korea should strictly follow Kim Il Sung's teachings, so I did as I was supposed to and kept a diary. Even though Kim Il Sung is a villain here, in North Korea he's above everything. We learned that he studied well and gave our lives purpose. I lived according to those teachings. I wrote these out of loyalty to the Leader. That was our ideology, and I lived my life in strict adherence to it. No one could think differently.I got hold of these diaries 10 years after I arrived in South Korea. I had been sending money to my family in the North and they sent them to me. I didn't write any complaints in diaries. I would've been in big trouble if I did. My diaries are a record of my history in North Korea. I am thinking about turning these diaries into a book. I'd like to publish a book about how to change North Koreans' thinking when unification happens. These diaries show how North Koreans think and how their minds are constructed. People need to make these into a textbook, because they need proof. Talking is not as effective.Song Byeok was a propaganda artist. His father drowned trying to cross the Tumen river, in 2000. When the artist finally left North Korea in 2001, he brought photos of his family with him. We left that August to find food, Byeok recalled, describing the first attempt. We were from a town further inland, and we weren't sure where the river was high and where it was low. I didn't know at the time but the river was swollen because of the rainy season. I thought we had to cross it anyway. All I could think about was getting to China to buy food. I took off my clothes and tied them into a rope to strap us together. I told my father not to let go. As we approached the middle of the river, the strap felt lighter. I looked back and saw my father drifting away. I was devastated.He was going under the water and couldn't get out. I rushed up to the (North Korean) border guards and asked them to save him but they just said why did I come out, why didn't I die too. They handcuffed me and took me away. It was Aug. 28. I was tortured by the bowibu (North Korean secret police) in Hoeryong, then jailed for four months in Chongjin prison camp. But after I was released from the camp I felt like I needed to survive and carry on living. Right before I tried to defect again, I went back home and grabbed my family photos. Even if I died trying, I thought, at least I would have this picture with me. I never found my father. After I came to South Korea, I went back to China in 2004 and held a memorial service for him by the river. My heart still aches.Baek Hwa-sung, 33, left Sinuiju, on the border with China, in 2003 and resettled in South Korea in 2008. He kept a diary as he defected. In 2004, I started to write down all my thoughts in a diary. I didn't know if I'd get caught. I just wanted to let it be known where I was from, and where I wanted to go. After I left the North, I became very depressed, hiding in the mountains alone for a while. The people who were watching over me told me not to come down to the village and left me by myself in a mountain shelter. Alone, with no one to engage with or talk to, I felt like I would go insane. So I wanted to leave something behind in case I died there or got caught - that's why I started to write.Alone in the mountains, I desperately sought something to talk to. That was my diary. My diaries are proof of my life's journey. I read them when I want to remember home. I can't return home, and I already have no memories of my hometown. But when I go through my diaries, there are notes which detail the vivid memories of that time. Sometimes I might forget my father's birthday, but when I go back to my diary, his birthday and my mother's birthday are there. My diaries are a record of my life. They prove I'm alive.North Korea has been preparing for an extravagant celebration for its national foundation day on 9 September.The festivities are intended to be a spectacular homage to Mr Kim’s campaign to bolster his country’s image abroad and ease tensions on the Korean Peninsula through diplomacy with its neighbours and the US.Diplomacy with China and Russia appears to be progressing, with reports Chinese tourism to North Korea is already on the rise.But it remains to be seen whether the initially successful negotiations between the north and Washington will progress, after Pyongyang called on Washington to make a stronger effort to build confidence and assure its security before it gives up its nuclear weapons.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

title: brexit news second eu referendum survey alistair burt andrew bridgen
story: Tory frontbencher Alistair Burt, who backed the Remain campaign in the run up to the 2016 in-or-out poll, launched a survey on his constituency website seeking local views on the possibility of a re-run of the historic vote on the UK's links with Brussels.He said he wanted to gauge opinion in his North East Bedfordshire patch after a number of constituents had contacted his office to express anger and concern about the progress with the country's withdrawal from the EU.But Eurosceptic Tory MPs accused him of breaching government policy given Theresa May's repeated rejection of demands for a second EU referendum.Tory MP and Leave campaigner Andrew Bridgen said: Alistair Burt is an arch-Europhile. I hope this is not an indication of the way Government policy is heading.Former Tory aide INFURIATES radio host in Brexit rowTrade expert predicts second Brexit referendum by end of 2018We haven't yet implemented the will of the people from the first referendum.I am not finding anyone in North West Leicestershire asking me for a second referendum.In fact, I am getting a lot of Remain voters telling me that the way the negotiations are going mean we cannot stay in the EU.They say that Brussels would treat us as a doormat if we stayed so we have got to get out.Alistair Burt has come under fire for asking voters for a second referendum  (Image: NC )Another senior Tory said: This is a complete breach of government policy. Alistair Burt needs to be reminded of his responsibilities under the principle of government collective responsibility.If he wants to keep his job, he should remove this survey immediately.A message on Mr Burt's website said: As discussions on Brexit continue, I have received many emails from constituents &ndash on both sides of the debate &ndash angry and concerned about how this process is progressing.I am keen to hear your views, and would be interested to see your answers to the questions below.MPs have backed the People's Vote campaign (Image:  )The survey then asked constituents to answer yes or no to the question: Do you support a further vote on the referendum?A second question asked: If there was a further vote, what should it cover?Four options were put forward by the website including a vote on the final deal, a re-run of the original referendum with in-out choices, a choice between three options of 'hard' Brexit, 'soft' Brexit or remaining in the EU, or having no further vote.Mr Burt's survey last night threatened to intensify the deepening Tory row over Europe.A second EU referendum in a new survey was posted (Image:  )A growing number of Eurosceptic Tories are concerned that the Prime Minister will come under pressure to grant a second referendum given the support for the move at the Westminster.Dozens of MPs from all the main political parties have backed the People's Vote campaign demanding a fresh poll even though both the Tory and Labour leaderships are opposed to the idea.Following yesterday's outcry, Mr Burt later updated his website to insist he was not in favour of a second referendum.He wrote: In view of the interest shown in the Brexit Survey I launched recently, I have made it clear to constituents who have written to me that I do not favour a second referendum.                'A coup by the RICH!' MEP warns of consequences of second Brexit vote                Tory MP SHUTS DOWN Alastair Campbell in fiery Brexit deateThe minister went on to set out his reasons for opposing a second referendum, including the fact that no mention of a second referendum was made at the original poll in 2016.Mr Burt also acknowledged a second referendum would not settle the issue and suggested a narrow vote to Remain could lead to calls for yet another poll.Neither the UK nor the EU benefits from prolonged, generational uncertainty of the UK seemingly unable to make its mind up, he saidMr Burt added: I have made repeatedly clear that the best way forward is to recognise that the UK remains deeply but almost evenly ided on the issue of membership of the EU.In 40 years of support for it, I and others have not been able to persuade the UK of its merits. I remain sorry about that, but accept it.And there&rsquos no going back. We should make the best of our situation and find a resolution for the best for both the UK and the EU and I am wholeheartedly behind the PM&rsquos efforts to do so.However, my constituents are entitled to their opinions and I&rsquom entitled to ask what they are, through a simple survey with a variety of options. That&rsquos all I have sought to do, and the survey has been out for some time with no adverse comment.In the referendum on the UK&rsquos membership of the EU in June 2016, 17.4million people voted to Leave the bloc while 16.1million voted to Remain.

story: EU chiefs want to toughen regulations to ensure that all new tyres fitted to vehicles on public roads are printed with information about their fuel efficiency, safety and noise standards.And even though the UK is due to quit the EU next year, British drivers could still be affected by the change - expected in 2020 if agreed by MEPs - because Brussels regulations are due to remain in force after Brexit under Theresa May's plans.Campaigners from the Brexit-backing grassroots pressure group Get Britain Out claimed the move could add up to &pound15 to the price of a tyre for a middle-range family saloon through increased production and design costs.Jayne Adye, director of Get Britain Out, said: &ldquoThis proposed EU regulation demonstrates how out of touch the European Commission is with the real world.Motorists could be penalised by the EU regulations   (Image: NC)Whilst it may look good on paper over in Brussels, this regulation would harm British motorists and farmers burdened with extra costs.&ldquoThere are many pieces of legislation, such as this one, which are set to come into force before December 2020 and the end of the Brexit transition period.It is imperative we leave as soon as possible to avoid such red tape entering our statute book.She added: &ldquoThe Commission has no intention of stopping with this piece of regulation.                Cyclists should face same punishment as drivers, says motoring lawyer                 Car tax changes could see YOU charged based on the amount of miles ...The revised energy labels for tyres strengthen the requirements on fuel efficiency, noise and safety, and will apply to tyres on all road-using vehicles including cars, vans and lorries.EU officials say the new labelling will be beneficial for the environment by increasing fuel efficiency and reducing greenhouse gas emissions.&nbsp It will lead to CO2 savings equivalent of removing almost four million passenger cars from EU roads per year by 2030, according to Brussels estimates.The RAC last night backed the new labelling system. RAC spokesman Simon Williams said: &ldquoStrengthening the tyre labelling regulations is good news for UK motorists and road safety generally.Currently, there is no requirement for tyre fitters to show labels at the point of purchase so motorists are oblivious to the pros and cons of the tyres they are buying.As a result few motorists are shown the labels when buying tyres, leaving them completely in the dark about the three ratings of fuel efficiency, wet grip and passing noise.Updating the regulations should fix this by making it mandatory for tyre labels to be shown to motorists in all situations.&ldquoInformation on tyres&rsquo snow and ice performance is going to be included which will be very beneficial.The labels are also being future-proofed as the amended regulations allow for the addition of other useful information such as ratings for mileage, wear and a potential indication for re-treaded tyres.                Bulgarian jailed for Ayrshire crash that killed pensioner                British motorist lands &pound36,000 in speeding fines in just FOUR hours...The International Tyre Manufacturers' Association has also backed the proposals.In a statement to the EU earlier this year, the association's president Alfred Graham said: &ldquoITMA is fully supportive of any measure that improves tyre safety, an objective the introduction the tyre-labelling regulation sought to achieve.If that means more can be done to increase motorists&rsquo awareness and understanding of the information on the labels, ITMA will gladly play its part.A critical element of the scheme was to inform consumers of the relative value and environmental benefits of the tyres they are considering buying, so they might be able to make an informed purchasing decision.Achieving that is essential if further performance ratings are to be added to the labelling, a proposal which ITMA also believes has merit, especially for winter and re-tread tyres.Fundamentally, of course, the accurate and consistent assessment of tyre performance is critical and to the benefit of all parties.Should viable means to enhancing existing practises be found, ITMA would once again be supportive of such changes.

title: Blindness cure sight restored mice gene therapy
story: This allowed mice to regain their vision after about six weeks (Image: )A team of US scientists from the National Institutes of Health used a gene injection to reprogramme dumb non-seeing retinal cells, and then use them to replace damaged light-sensitive rod cells.&nbspThis is the first time researchers have managed to replace damaged retinal cells, leading to hopes that the same process could one day be applied to humans.&nbspThe study demonstrated that it is possible to restore lost light-sensitive cells in the eye, by putting a gene into the retinal cells and using it to reorientate them.&nbspThis allowed mice to regain their vision after about six weeks.&nbsp                Punish patients who miss appointments with &pound5 says GPHowever during the study only rods were restored, which provide vision in low light.&nbspBut the researchers hope conserving the rods will also protect cones, the other type of retinal cell which is integral to sight.&nbspDr Bo Chen, one of the researchers, said: &ldquoThis is very powerful cell repair machinery.&nbsp&ldquoThe major strength of the research is this can be applied to the wider spectrum of retinal degenerative diseases.&nbspIf this works this could transform the way we treat patients with retinal disease (Image: )&ldquoIf this works, this could transform the way we treat patients with retinal disease and possibly learn how to cure other types of eye disease like glaucoma.Dr Chen added that the human eye has the same essential structure, though the process cannot yet be replicated in humans.&nbspHe explained: &ldquoThe basic structure is still there.&nbsp&ldquoBut for some reason it is inhibited.&nbspThe scientists studied zebrafish as part of their investigation, which already have the ability to convert retinal nerve cells into the vital rod cells.&nbspHelen Lee, from the Royal National Institute of Blind People welcomed the news saying:&nbspThe scientists studied zebrafish as part of title: atmosphere mesosphere cloud formation space weather forecast
story: Researchers were baffled by the late blood of noctilucent clouds (Image: SPACE WEATHER)Scientists have been scratching their heads over late blossoming cloud formations which were seen in the mesosphere &ndash the region in the Earth&rsquos atmosphere between 50 and 80 kilometres above the surface, almost touching space.The strange thing is not that there has been noctilucent clouds (NLCs) &ndash clouds formed when summertime water vapour rises to the edge of space and forms long streaks of ice crystals in the sky &ndash but that they are appearing so late in the year.NLCs typically form in May, become intense in June before fading in July.However, this year, they have reached their peak in late July, heading into August, and exploding &ldquowith unusual luminosity.                UK long term weather: Rains here but cold snap could last 11 YEARS                Massive man-made star will be visible in night sky from EarthWebsite Space Weather says that reports of NLCs in August have tripled in comparison to the same time last year.But researchers have stated that this is due to an unexpected surge of water vapour in the mesosphere.Lynn Harvey of Colorado's Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics (LASP) said: There has been an unexpected surge of water vapour in the mesosphere.July went out like a lion!The clouds form in the mesosphere (Image: Randy Russell, UCAR)Still, it remains unclear why there is so much water vapour so late in the year.One theory is to do with the upcoming solar minimum.The sun follows cycles of roughly 11 years where it reaches a solar maximum and then a solar minimum.During a solar maximum, the sun gives off more heat and is littered with sunspots. Less heat in a solar minimum is due to a decrease in magnetic waves.The sun was not expected to head into a solar minimum until around 2020, but it appears to be heading in earlySpace Weather says: &ldquoThe phenomenon could be linked to solar minimum, now underway. It is notable that the coldest and wettest years in the mesosphere prior to 2018 were 2008-2009&ndashthe previous minimum of the 11-year solar cycle.&ldquoAnother possibility involves planetary wave activity in the southern hemisphere which can, ironically, boost the upwelling of water vapour tens of thousands of miles away in the north.

title: a level results grade boundaries ucas points track clearing explained
story: Today is the day anxious teenagers will find out if months of hard work have been worth it.Students across the nation will finally figure out how their exams went, with results beginning to go live at 8am, Thursday, August 16.The results will be out on UCAS feature, Track, from 8am, but you can also contact you collect or university to check if you have been accepted.When you have received your results you, head to UCAS to calculate your UCAS points.                A-levels results day 2018: What are the A-level grade boundaries? O...                A Levels 2018 results LIVE: Latest as UK students discover gradesA-level results day: Students will find out how their exams went today (Image: )UCAS pointsThe UCAS Tariff points are allocated to qualifications generally studied doing your A-levels.To work out how many UCAS points your qualifications are worth you need to:1. Select your qualification from the drop-down list.A-level results day 2018: The results will be on UCAS feature, Track (Image: )2. Enter the subject you're studying (this is optional).3. Select your grade from the drop-down list &ndash the Tariff points for this qualification will display automatically next to your grade.4. When you've entered all your qualifications, click on the &ldquonext button.Be aware that a lot of the qualifications are not on the Tariff points, and this does not mean you have not been accepted into the university of your choice.                A Level results day 2018: UCAS Clearing - how does Clearing work?                Students can get A-Level &lsquoA&rsquo mark with FIFTY PERCENT in some exams Some universities and colleges use UCAS points in their entry requirements, which means you need to check how many points your qualifications are worth.See more on that HERE.&nbspGrade boundariesThe grade boundaries shows the minimum number of marks required for each grade.A-level results day 2018: The results came out at 8am this morning (Image: )Grade boundaries will be published from 8am today, same as the exam results, and are available on each exam board&rsquos website.Each exam board has its own grade boundary.Previously the boundaries have been realised online the day before students receive their A-level results, but since 2017 it has been changed to be published the same day.The different grade boundaries used are OCR, EdexcelPearson, AQA and CCEA.You can read more about this on our  grade boundaries guide.A-level results day 2018: Youngsters will find out if months of hard work has paid off (Image: )How does UCAS Clearing work?UCAS, the website every university student in the UK uses to apply for a place, has a system to ensure students find a university with the grades they have achieved.UCAS Clearing gives students the chance to change their mind about which university to attend, to apply for a degree at the last minute or to alter choices once grades have been revealed.Using the dedicated website and your already existing UCAS account, you can search for courses.Once you have found a course and wish to apply - there will be an &lsquoAdd A Clearing Choice&rsquo option found on the &lsquoNext Steps&rsquo page.However, unlike the usual five choices you get when first applying with UCAS, Clearing only allows one choice.If you don&rsquot progress with your first choice Clearing university, you are allowed to choose another.

title: brexit negotiations theresa may eu leaders salzburg summit september
story: According to diplomatic sources, suggestions Mrs May could negotiate with the 27 other EU heads of state and government at a summit in Salzburg have been rejected out of hand.One European source said: &ldquoThat is completely ridiculous, that is complete overspin of Salzburg.&ldquoIt would mean that we would ditch our negotiating approach of the last two years and discuss at 28 instead of 27 to one, and I don&rsquot see why this would happen.The comments came after Mrs May&rsquos office announced Brexit would be on the agenda at the September 20 talks after after discussions with Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz.                 Britain will THRIVE: Hunt dismisses No Deal scaremongering                Is MI6 BUGGING the Brexit talks? EU officials raise concerns European Union leaders will discuss Brexit when they next meet in the Austrian city of Salzburg on Sept. 20, British Prime Minister Theresa May&rsquos office saidA spokesman said: &ldquoThe summit will also cover illegal migration, and on this the Prime Minister confirmed that the UK will continue to work closely with the EU now and after Brexit.Brexit talks resume in Brussels today with the aim of reaching a deal by the autumn.EU bosses have always insisted all formal talks are led by chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier and while Mrs May is allowed to update EU leaders on her plans at quarterly EU summits, she is not in the room for discussions.Theresa May and Sebastian Kurz in Salzburg last month (Image: )Theresa May wants direct talks with fellow EU leaders (Image: )Officials expect this approach to be continued at Salzburg where an informal summit on September 20 is being held to discuss the migration crisis.The meeting has been organised by Austria, which currently holds the EU rotating presidency, but it will be for the European council president Donald Tusk to decide whether to add Brexit to the agenda.Salzburg comes four weeks before an EU summit in Brussels at which Mr Barnier hopes to strike a deal.Many in Brussels expect the deadline to slip to November or even December, squeezing the time available to ratify the text ahead of the UK&rsquos departure on March 29, 2019.                Germany MUST pay for Brexit EU budget shortfall, claims expert                Fury as top Tory launches second EU referendum bidMrs May has tried to get round Mr Barnier by appealing directly to national capitals for greater flexibility, a strategy continued by Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt who is on a three-day Brexit tour on the continent this week.Few are expecting a dramatic breakthrough from this week&rsquos low-key Brexit negotiations in Brussels, which will be led by officials rather than Mr Barnier and the new Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab.The Irish border issue tops the agenda for today&rsquos talks with both sides deeply ided over how to avoid customs checks at the crossing.Tomorrow&rsquos sessions will be devoted to the UK&rsquos future relationship with the EU as outlined in Mrs May&rsquos Chequers blueprint.Dominic Raab and Michel Barnier (Image: )Brussels sees serious flaws in the Chequers plan and has dismissed Mrs May&rsquos customs ideas as unworkable but negotiators have not entirely written off the plan and see the kernel of a free-trade agreement.EU officials insist they cannot break up the EU&rsquos single market and its &ldquofour freedoms of goods, capital, services and people.A diplomat said: &ldquoI can&rsquot imagine we would walk away from that.&ldquoIt is the raison d&rsquo&ecirctre of the EU. We can&rsquot have Brexit threaten our political and economic system.

title: a level 2018 results how to resit when to resit a levels
story: Not all students will receive the the results they had hoped for today but luckily there are ways you can still get into your dream university.Resitting an exam might not be what already anxious students had hoped for but many people are in the same boat.If resitting is not an option, you can look through UCAS Clearing to see if there is anything suitable for you.Going into a full-time job or an apprenticeship is also an option, if you want to leave the time as an A-level student behind you.                What are the A-level grade boundaries? OCR, Edexcel, AQA and more                A-level results: Grade boundaries and UCAS points explainedA-level 2018 results: You can resit your exams if you didn't get accepted into your dream university (Image: )How and when to resit your A-levelsThe first thing you should do when resitting your A-level exams is to talk to your college or school first, as you might be able to retake your exam there.Not all schools offers this but luckily, there are tons of other options.If you are not planning on sitting the exams in your old school or college, you can do it at an exam centre but you will need to provide the centre with your old candidate details.A-level 2018 results: If resitting is not an option, you can look through UCAS Clearing (Image: )The downside of retaking A-level exams at an independent college is that it can cost a lot of money.A-levels can only be done once per year and exams normally happen in June.This means you can enrol to retake the exams the following year.The option of taking A-level exams in January is unfortunately no longer available.Remember you can only resit your exams once.                Students can get A-Level &lsquoA&rsquo mark with FIFTY PERCENT in some exams                 A Level 2018 results LIVE: Latest as UK students discover gradesA-level 2018 results: A-levels can only be done once per year, and normally happens in June (Image: )In most cases you will have to retake the whole A-level, and end up with two grades, one from your original grade and one from your retake.In some subjects you might be able to use assessments submitted in your old course, as long a they are non-examined assessments.When you have decided on resitting your exams, you need to officially decline any offers you have received from universities by September 20.Your school or college will most likely be able to help you with further advice on what to do, so talk to an exams co-ordinator about what your best options are.Bear in mind, although most universities accept resits, offers might be slightly higher.The upside to retaking your A-level can be an opportunity to show the university you are committed to your studies, and shows independence.

story: For some poor students, A-level results day turned out to be a disappointment rather than a celebration.If you did not get the results you were hoping for, try not to worry.Some students have been left confused after receiving the grades from their exams, wondering if they have passed A-levels.Read below to find out what grade you need to be able to advance into higher education. title: Weather forecast UK Met Office latest heatwave hot weather august 2018 weekend
story: Freakishly hot weather could hold out through September and possibly into October, according to some long-range forecasters.A plume of warm, sultry air will sweep into Britain during the middle of next week just as the nation starts to cool down.Temperatures could reach their highest so far this summer with the 38.5C (101.3F) record still under threat, experts say.Only Scotland and parts of northern England will escape the sweltering steam-bath although it will be warmer than average across much of the UK.                UK HOT weather forecast: Britain faces 43C temp as HOTTEST spell hits                UK weather forecast: Britain braces for CONTINENTAL SCORCHERJames Madden, forecaster for Exacta Weather, warned Britain could be facing another lengthy heatwave.He said: &ldquoOur models show we are about to go into another period of prolonged summery weather, there is a growing likelihood we could see another extreme heat surge during the second half of this month.&ldquoIt is not out of the question that Britain will bask in some of the highest temperatures of summer to date, even beating those seen over the past two months.&ldquoThere is every chance this summer will come in as the hottest on record as temperatures rise back into the mid 30Cs at the very least.&ldquoLonger-range projections show the possibility of warm weather continuing into the start of the meteorological autumn and even into October.Britons have been urged to make the most of a brief cooler spell which will bring a drop in temperatures over the next couple of days.UK weather forecast: Britain is set to sizzle as the UK heatwave returns (Image: NETWEATHER)Torrential rain will hammer swathes of the country as a cold front moves in from the Atlantic on Wednesday night.Northern Britain will be first in the firing line before downpours pelt the south and southeast on Thursday morning.The rain will clear through the day making way for much fresher air to bring temperatures down widely, the Met Office said.Meteorologist Bonnie Diamond said: &ldquoQuite an active front will move over Wales and northern England on Wednesday evening bringing some heavy rain.&ldquoThis will move into the southeast of the country through Thursday morning and it will be a much fresher day with maximum temperatures of around 21C (69.8F).&ldquoFriday is looking more unsettled in the north again with a drier, nicer day forecast elsewhere although it will still feel fresher compared to the start of the week.                BBC weather forecast: Temperatures to SOAR &ndash but not before a storm                Four more years of heatwaves on wayUK weather forecast: Temperatures are set to soar back to 30C this week (Image: NETWEATHER)Rain will continue to pelt Scotland and northwestern England over the weekend with sunshine confined to the south, she said.South-eastern England will hold on to the fine weather into next week as temperatures start to head upwards, she added.She said: &ldquoFrom the middle of next week onwards there will be a good deal of dry, bright weather in the southeast as a result this part of the country will be back to warm or very warm temperatures.&ldquoIt is also going to be humid as tropical air moves into southern Britain, later next week we are expecting temperatures in the high 20Cs.&ldquoThe longer-range outlook shows there is a possibility of the warm or very warm weather lasting in the southeast, it will be more unsettled in northern parts of the country.Warm weather will hold out at least until the end of the month meaning Britons will enjoy another bank holiday scorcher.

title: ebenezer cobb morley who was google doodle father of football FA
story: Ebenezer was born on August 16, 1831, in Hull, England.At 27 he moved to Barnes, London, where he worked as a solicitor and rowed along the Thames in his free time.Ebenezer made his first stamp on the sporting world when he founded the Barnes and Mortlake Regatta in 1862 and competed in the Grand Challenge Cup at Henley in 1864.His real legacy, however, lies in being the first person to write the rules of football.                Google Doodle celebrates influential philosopher Ibn Sina - who was...Before Ebenezer set the rules of the &lsquobeautiful game&rsquo to paper, football was said to be a chaotic sport with no organised competitions.But the lawyer saw the potential in the sport, and formed the Barnes Club, a founding member of the FA, in 1862.In 1863, as captain of the club, he wrote to Bell&rsquos Life newspaper, proposing governing body for the game.In an attempt to garner financial and academic support, he appealed to some of the nation&rsquos most prestigious schools to get involved, but was rebuffed.Undeterred, Ebenezer convened a meeting at the Freemason&rsquos Tavern in Holborn on October 26, 1863, which would go down in history.Ebenezer Cobb Morley: Ebenezer set the rules of the &lsquobeautiful game&rsquo to paper (Image: GettyTwitter@ForStatue)The meeting was attended by representatives of future football giants, including Blackheath, Perceval House, Kensington School, the War Office, Crystal Palace, the Crusaders, Charterhouse and No Names of Kilburn.With this, the Football Association was born, with Ebenezer at the helm as its first secretary and then president.His original draft of 23 rules included a provision allowing players to &ldquohack the front of the leg, which proved controversial.The isive rule was eventually scrapped, and the finalised version was published in the FA&rsquos December 1863 pamphlet, Laws of the Game.These rules were adopted across London and, eventually, spread across the world. title: the sun reader letters boris burka
story: But there has been a groundswell of support for BoJo from ordinary people, fed up at what they see as attacks on freedom of expression and the British way of life.This is what Sun readers have to say about the issue, and Brexit-backer Boris:BORIS Johnson has a dig at burka-wearing Muslims and our elite shake with fear. Don’t they know many thousands of people agree with him? Or do they chose to again ignore the people of this country? Any movement on Boris from the out-of-touch Government will cost them dear.SO Dominic Grieve has threatened to quit Parliament if Boris Johnson became PM. I can think of no better reason for wishing him success.BANG on Boris, about the burka. It being worn in public is scary for children who see it.FREEDOM of speech must not be compromised – and there can be no question of legal action being taken against Boris Johnson, it would be prejudiced by all the attacks on him.THIS week it has been especially hard to be a Muslim woman. Apparently I am not getting the joke, I’m over sensitive, bullied, oppressed, unintegrated, politically motivated, dividing Britain – this list goes on. Perhaps Boris Johnson’s Etonian education did not enable him to understand that in polite society it’s rude to comment with ridicule on the way people dress.ONE thing critics of Boris Johnson’s burka comment overlook is the impact of burka-wearers on those who are deaf and rely on seeing facial expressions, and lip-reading.THE do-gooders complaining about Boris are fanning the flames of hatred by highlighting issues that one wouldn’t really think about. Talk about “integration” appears to be one-sided and discriminatory towards the indigenous people. There is some equilibrium lacking in our “fair, just and equal” land of ours.WHILE I am not sure Boris used a good choice of words likening women in burkas to pillar boxes, he was right that we are frightened by what it represents. We must not destroy Boris, he is good for the people of this country, he cares. He must also be allowed to speak honestly, he has nothing to apologise for.LIGHTEN up, Boris spoke the thoughts of many millions of Brits. If making a gaffe was against the law, Prince Philip could have been banged up in the Tower of London on many occasions during the last 50 years. He wrote the book on it.Boris might have an agenda – what politician doesn’t? – but this mustn’t mean people don’t have a right to voice criticism. Face veils in public, and burkas, are not religious requirements and we must have the right to criticise the wearers.IF I was Boris Johnson, I would agree to attend the diversity training some have suggested . . . and then tear the training session to pieces.I SAW Ranvir Singh berating her guests on morning TV for daring to agree with Boris Johnson? I wonder what her bosses would say if she suggested that she presented her programme wearing a burka. I think we all know the answer to that.PHIL GROWDENNOTHING Theresa May says can be taken at face value. Not so long ago, she promised to stop the witch-hunt of British soldiers, who have seen action and survived in many parts of the world. However, the victimisation of our veterans continues unabated. They are now joined by Boris Johnson, who has frequently ignited the Prime Minister’s wrath and must therefore, be thrown to the wolves.A BUS company has apologised after a driver told a woman to remove her niqab. So would a bank apologise if a security guard asked a man to remove his ski mask?HOW would I stand as a Christian male finding a Muslim lady, dressed in a burka, having a heart attack? Would I be allowed to remove her veil to perform mouth-to-mouth?THE controversy surrounding Boris Johnson’s burka comments has reached ridiculous heights. Police conducting an investigation. Really?IF Theresa May had the guts to ban the burka like a lot of other countries, we might not be having this discussion about what Boris Johnson said.SOMETHING featureless with a rectangular hole in it can resemble a letter box, there’s probably one on your front door, go and have a look. It has also been known for the person inside to be a terrorist, not an innocent woman. Stop being so pathetic, have a sense of humour, act like adultsI READ about a motorcyclist at a filling station having to remove his crash helmet while a woman (who could have been a criminal’s getaway driver) filling up at the pump next to him was wearing a burka. Meanwhile Boris’s remarks are causing hysteria.I HAVE been visiting garden centres and supermarket car parks in my car, which is bedecked with Brexit stickers, asking many people their opinion on the Boris situation. For Boris, I find there is a great deal of love out there. For the Chequers “deal” there is none.IT’S true that Boris Johnson has used strong language but Muslim terrorists are doing far worse things than robbing banks, by committing terrorist atrocities. It would be a sad day when the Muslim community can’t take such a comment, especially when many Muslim women, in my view, do not want this clothing themselves.IT’S confirmed, lunatics are ruining the country. We have the enemy (EU) knocking art the door and all the idiots can find to discuss is Boris Johnson’s perfectly fair comment. If it wasn’t so serious it would be funny. Brexit should be top of the agenda.THERE are easily as many people who agree with BoJo’s comments as those who don’t. So why is it those who don’t will instigate an investigation, leaving those who do without a voice? Even senior Muslims and imams have said that the burka is not a requirement in Islam, so why is it we only tend to listen to those who are offended?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the last leg ally ross
story: You expect this reaction, obviously, from news organisations who have to fill endless blank hours with something during silly season.The really depressing thing, though, was that a late-night Channel 4 “comedy” show and its presenters were the most outraged of them all.I’m talking, of course, about The Last Leg which, for reasons that still escape me, genuinely fancies itself as one of television’s edgiest and funniest shows.It’s not, clearly. The Last Leg is a television safe space, the authentic voice of the PC establishment and as predictable as the sun rising in the morning.So you knew, long before Friday’s transmission, that they’d be targeting Boris, who is a thousand times funnier and edgier than anyone on this show, in his own way.Nearly a whole working week host Adam Hills and his two mates had to prepare some decent material as well, and this was the best three professional comedians could do.Alex Brooker: “The burka is an item of clothing worn by a human being, the other is a postbox, you f***ing idiot.”Adam Hills: “I’d much rather sit next to a person in burka than a p***k in a suit.”Josh Widdicombe: “Theresa May has only just realised Boris is a t**t, so she should apologise as well.”On and on it went, for 12 minutes and 54 seconds, a figure I mention because I’ve had the clock on this lot, and if you want to know exactly how much of a toss they really give about religious sensitivities then it’s best measured by the fact this series of The Last Leg has devoted just 65 hand-wringing seconds to the anti-Semitic poison infecting the Labour Party.It was crammed hurriedly into the previous episode, which was worth watching just to see Adam Hills describe Corbyn’s handling of this crisis as “a faux pas”, (which isn’t French for “shameful cluster-f***”) and the C4 audience react with evident discomfort because he’d drawn attention to the Labour leader’s failings and, therefore, broken one of comedy’s secret and golden rules.If you doubted these rules exist, incidentally, then ever the virtue-signalling fool, Adam Hills was good enough to spell them out for us on Friday.“Every religion should be open to ridicule . . . but you kind of need to be in the club.“Alex and I can make jokes about disabilities as we’re technically disabled.”Boris, he then explained, can’t make jokes about burkas, ’cos he’s “a white Etonian”, nor could comedy giant Rowan Atkinson defend him, as he was “a white man who lives in Oxford and drives an F1 car”.Even if we ignore the fact he’s assumed that all Muslims are black, something pretty staggering is going on here.For Mary Whitehouse, in all her pearl-clutching glory, never imagined anything quite as Draconian and controlling as this form of satirical Apartheid.Adam Hills has a point, though, when he uses the word “club”. That’s exactly what television comedy has become.A closed, left-wing shop where you don’t even bother joining the audience unless you follow the rigid “Tories and Brexit are evil” party line.This is not creating comedy, it’s policing it, and also the reason why applause has replaced laughter on all those Channel 4 and BBC news satires which have failed to realise there is only one simple rule to be observed when creating these shows: Make it funny, dumbo.I would suggest, at this point, Adam Hills gets off his moral high horse, for once, and gives this “funny” idea a go.But then I could also ask Boris to have a crack at anchoring the British women’s 4x100m relay team to gold at the next Olympics, wearing a burka, and I’d know there was only the remotest chance of one ever happening.Run Boris, run.MEANWHILE, back on Channel 4’s Meet The Drug Lords: Inside The Real Narcos, Jason “Foxy” Fox was with the Colombian navy this week and desperate for a look inside one of the incredible home-made submarines they’d confiscated from drug-smugglers.“Is it locked?”“Yes.”And there’ll be more Bafta-worthy action from Foxy and his forward-planning department this week, I’m sure.EVER since it discovered that Danny Dyer was the rightful heir to the English throne, Who Do You Think You Are? has been struggling to find a purpose, or indeed a celebrity, who could see the bigger picture.That special someone who would acknowledge history’s great events with more than a few “wows” and shrugs and not think their own career made all of their ancestors’ suffering worthwhile.Finally, last night, they found him.Judge Robert Rinder, who as well as having the best brain at ITV (Luna the Labrador off This Morning has the second best) also turns out to be a natural television journalist, telling the story of his maternal great-grandfather, Israel, and his beloved grandfather, Morris, simply, beautifully and without ever letting the details overwhelm him.The former fled revolutionary Latvia at the turn of the last century.The latter’s entire family was wiped out in Treblinka’s gas chambers.Yet he somehow survived the Buchen-wald, Theresienstadt and Schlieben concentration camps and made it to Britain, which offered him salvation, friendship, justice and, above all, a sense that “life is worth living” that has been passed down through eternally grateful generations.It’s a remarkable story, so if you missed it, try to catch tonight’s repeat (BBC1, 11.25pm).SCENES and characters the viewers are unlikely to forget in a hurry on the final episode of BBC2’s wonderful Travels In Trumpland With Ed Balls.First stop, the President’s Mar-a-Lago compound in Florida, where Ed spent the most uncomfortable night of his life, since Strictly, at a one-year-in-office party for Trump, with Toni Holt Kramer and a group of fans who were called The Trumpettes, but could well have been the provisional wing of The Golden Girls.If you thought they were a bit sinister, though, he was then off squirrel hunting in the forests of Georgia with two hillbillies who might not have been plucking banjos but they certainly had the mad cackling laughs and slightly unsettling line in hospitality.“Are you ready to be a man today, Ed?” asked one, as you began to wonder if he could escape with his dignity intact, let alone blend in with the local gene pool.Then he suddenly reappeared – and this was a masterstroke – wearing a Norwich City scarf.Scrub everything I ever said about Ed Balls.The man’s a diplomatic genius.Sent in by Rob Milner, East Yorkshire. title: first part time jobs sun writers
story: The number of 16 to 17-year-olds taking part-time jobs has more than halved since 1997, dropping from 42 per cent to 18 per cent. It means young people are missing out on essential skills as they approach adulthood.GRANT ROLLINGS asked five Sun columnists what their first part-time jobs were and the valuable lessons they learned – from being polite to skiving.I ALWAYS had a summer job, usually it meant working full-time hours on my normal Saturday job as holiday cover. This was either in a boutique such as Chelsea Girl or in BHS, where I worked on the sweetie counter.I coped with the boredom by sneakily munching on the best chocolate sweets from the pick-and-mix. I also worked as a waitress in a trendy Glasgow eaterie during the holidays.All of these jobs gave me the most enormous respect for the men and women who toil for long hours, often dealing with unreasonable members of the public for too little pay and not much prospect of promotion.Working in the service industry taught me the power of a disarming smile, and proved that my old granny’s saying that “you get more in life from sugar than vinegar” could not be more true.Grumpy customers demanding refunds and diners moaning that they had been waiting too long for their main course were usually placated with a swift apology and a promise to sort things out.A major restaurant blunder could often be smoothed over with a free coffee or pudding.MY favourite summer job came in 1977. I was a traffic enumerator for Middlesbrough Council. That meant I spent all day counting cars. All the way up one side of Linthorpe Road, all the way back down the other.I had to write down all the number plates. In the end, I got a bit bored and spent the time hanging out at my mate’s T-shirt shop or Fearnley Records and made the numbers up, always remembering to have them end in the local codes of HN or (I think) XG. I hope the council thought it worthwhile.It was better than the glue factory, where I’d been very briefly working on a weighbridge. Foreman pressed a button and this vast door opened and thousands of rotting animal carcasses fell out. I can still smell it now, all these years later. I passed out — soft lad, you see.Or there was working the nightshift pricing cans of food and stuff in Hintons, the local convenience store. Every time I turned up, the manager would say, ‘Here he is, the poor man’s Rod Stewart’.A friend of mine, Mark, had a much better summer job.He was a Club 18-30 holiday rep. He shagged 21 girls in 25 days, which gave me my first story to sell to the national newspapers.MY first holiday job was in the summer of 1985 when I was 16 years old. I had already been turned down from working at Waitrose in Enfield Town on the basis I was “too glamorous”.That just goes to show how far we have come in such a short time. I have never set foot in a Waitrose since that day because I was beyond furious. Anyway, the job I did get was working in a hairdresser’s on Goodge Street in London.My journey involved three changes and about 14 stops every day. The job was meant to be answering the phone, sweeping up and generally helping out, but before the end of the first week I was running the till, the appointment system, cashing up and generally managing the place.The only thing I could not do was cut hair, but that didn’t stop me cutting my friends’ hair — with very mixed results, more bad than good — on the basis I worked in a hairdresser’s so they thought I should. I remember the liberating feeling of earning my own money, it gave me the greatest sense of independence, self-esteem and self-belief.I worked out I was actually good in a work environment, talking to people — for example, talking women into perms they didn’t want — being responsible, handling money and making a difference to my employer.The biggest transition we make in our lives is leaving education to go into the workplace, and summer jobs prepare you for this.I HAD dozens of summer jobs, from working as a scaffolder’s mate with a convicted murderer, who kept a pistol in the glove compartment of his Ford Escort, to donning a white suit and Geiger counter to carry out maintenance on the core of the main reactor at a nuclear power station.I learned a hundred things from each and every job, but it was working as a grocery assistant at my local supermarket that had the most impact.My best friend and I both got jobs there at the same time. He was a star performer at school, a brilliant academic, but he couldn’t take the pace and got fired after a couple of months.It was incredibly hard, repetitive work.The manager was an ex-Army major — very strict on haircuts, discipline and stealing.There was always the prospect of the Tannoy announcement “customer service one hundred”, which was code for a shoplifter having been spotted.All the male floor staff were required to assemble at till number one to tackle the suspect, who would sometimes become violent.I was much happier making the cheese look pretty and eventually became the ruler of the entire soft dairy aisle — a project I’m still working on.I WAS 13 in Brownes Wine bar, Stafford Street, Derby, summer 1987, some years before it burned down in mysterious circumstances (has a bar ever burnt down innocently?). I was chief bottler-up.This involved the soul-sapping exercise of sifting through bins taller than me for all the recyclable bottles from the previous night’s festivities and putting them in their correct crates. This took all morning and you ended up cut to shreds and stinking of Britvic and Schlitz.I was then asked to be the cook — this involved microwaving lasagne for drunk people. I was paid the princely sum of £3 per hour. I realised how crap this was, so one scorching Saturday I nicked the shampoo that came with my dad’s company car and took advantage of the sketchy Eighties attitude to drink-driving and washed all the customers’ cars in the car park for a fiver a pop.I literally cleaned up. It was the greatest Dragons’ Den moment I’ve ever had. I waxed on and off all day, rinsing my dad of his prized BMW product. He arrived to pick me up and I was minted. A 13-year-old with £64 in his pocket. That coveted Swatch would finally be mine.He then told me the dog had been run over, so that’s another memory ruined.Thanks for reminding me.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn is unfit to be labour leader
story: His entire political career has been spent in close company with anti- Semites, terrorist sympathisers and extremists.So it shouldn’t be a surprise that he was pictured appearing to pay his respects to Black September, the terror group which murdered 11 Israelis and one German policeman at the Munich Olympics.That’s a group that not only killed in cold blood but tortured and brutalised their victims too.It is genuinely shocking that the Leader of the Opposition is so willing to lie about it. To say that he was “present but not involved” is an insult to voters’ intelligence when photographs show him holding a wreath and gurning for a nearby camera.To allow his press office to say the widows of those murdered in Munich were being “misled” is, even among the many shameful episodes we’ve seen since he became Labour leader three hate-filled years ago, disgraceful.The most vital qualification for power in this country must be integrity. And Jeremy Corbyn has demonstrated this week that he has absolutely none of it.But for all of the shame that he brings upon Labour, it is nothing compared to the spinelessness of the party’s “moderate” MPs whose opposition to Corbyn extends not much further than wishy-washy tweets.“Present but not involved” isn’t an excuse for Corbyn but nor is it for the cowards on Labour’s backbenches.Corbyn cannot be allowed near government. But the rest of the party has lost the public’s faith too.TOMORROW, official figures are likely to suggest that train fares will go up by another 3.5 per cent in January.If you’re a commuter who has put up with delayed and cancelled trains, you’ll be wondering what you’re paying for.After a disastrous year, there is no other industry that would turn round and ask customers for even more.The failure of the Government to take responsibility, blaming unions or claiming the cash is for “investment”, is simply not good enough. It’s the same as last year’s excuse.It is time for a radical overhaul — but that does not mean nationalisation. Far from it. Our railways need MORE private sector involvement.The hybrid system we have, in which private operators rely on publicly owned tracks and have their fares regulated by government, has led us into the worst of both worlds.Transport supremo Chris Grayling needs to take on the unions once and for all. And he needs to introduce real competition on the railways, giving operators far more freedom.Commuters deserve better than finger-pointing and higher fares.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rid harry and meghan turbulent
story: Most of the time, they make the Windsors seem a happy and (almost) normal bunch — no small feat.So why oh why is the Palace spin machine making such a spectacular mess with the Markles?Anybody with half a brain could tell, from the moment Prince Harry and Meghan started dating, that her family could turn into a royal pain in the neck.You’ve got a vengeful and jealous half-sister Samantha, who despises Meghan and has been briefing against her for more than a year.She is now telling hacks that she knows Harry and Meghan’s marriage won’t last, which is charming.Then you’ve got Thomas Markle, the dad, an eccentric character who is furious at being “locked out” of his daughter’s life.Barely a day goes by without Mr Markle hurling another negative headline across the Atlantic in the direction of his new son-in-law.Mr Markle insists that, contrary to official briefings, the rift between him and his daughter continues. He says he was told that he couldn’t speak at the wedding and that Harry berated him on the phone for mishandling the Press while he was recovering from a heart attack.The official royal response to these outbursts has been, effectively, to shove their fingers in their ears and shout la-la-la (or lah-lah-lah).The snobby courtiers and hangers-on dismiss Markle père as fame-hungry.That’s not altogether wrong — he is clearly desperate, as he proved by posing for snaps with the paparazzi in the run-up to the wedding.But it’s not good enough to wish he’d just go away.Meghan is now one of the most photographed and sought-after women in the world. Her very well-paid PR flunkies should have seen these familial landmines a mile off and defused them.But they have failed.Thomas Markle is a difficult and proud man, no doubt. But that is why he should have been treated with care, not frozen out.Why did Team Windsor not find him a role and approach him long before the wedding to make sure he didn’t feel excluded.It’s hard not to feel for him.His ex, Meghan’s mother Doria, was hailed as one of the stars of the wedding.Because she’s a black woman, she invited lots of gushing commentary about the monarchy becoming more diverse and modern.Amen to that. But poor old podgy Thomas, an awkward-looking white bloke, has been shunned from his daughter’s nuptials. You can’t blame him for speaking out.The royal courtiers enjoy the adulation the monarchy receives because Prince Harry has been “brave” enough to marry a woman with a complicated background.But the Palace spin machine freaks out when it comes to confronting the reality of Meghan’s parentage.Perhaps they just find it too vulgar.Harry’s PR man is Jason Knauf, an American specialist in “crisis management” having worked for Royal Bank of Scotland. He excels at sending angry letters to journalists he feels have gone too far snooping into Harry and Meghan’s private lives.But he doesn’t seem to have a clue as to how to handle his clients’ grumpy relatives.As a result, the monarchy is facing arguably its worst crisis since the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.We are often told how brilliant the Royal Family’s PR is. Part of the new royal spin, in fact, is about how great the royals now are at spin. They have “rebranded” the monarchy for the 21st century, and so on.Look at the blizzard of positive guff accompanying Prince William, Kate, and Harry’s campaign for mental illness last year.They were, it was said, making the younger Windsors seem more touchy-feely.At the moment, however, they don’t seem sensitive enough to speak to Meghan’s suffering in-laws.That’s not what you’d call a good look.The truth is, royal press officers have long got too much credit.The British admire the Queen because she is admirable.Overall, we prefer monarchy to any other system of government. That’s just common sense. It’s nothing to do with any ingenious branding and media strategy.The public also feels that the younger royals deserve a chance.At a time when our country is consumed by Brexit and political arguments, the wedding of Harry and Meghan came as a blessed relief — something we could all celebrate.The couple both came from broken homes, and nobody cared so long as they were happy. That’s all great.   But it’s obvious that Meghan has, as one royal expert put it, “background baggage that needs unpacking”.Insiders now say the treatment of the Markle family has been a “shambles”.This is before we consider the potential PR bombshells that could erupt if and when Meghan’s ex-husband, Trevor Engelson, decides to grant some interviews.The British don’t want to see the monarchy turned into a reality TV soap, as the Markles and Windsors wage a media war with each other.It’s trashy and embarrassing.But unless the Palace can tackle Meghan’s disgruntled kin, that’s exactly what is happening.Maybe we need a changing of the royal PR guard — before it’s too late.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: voices schizophrenia
story: But the truth is that Kyle is no killer, the blood splattered all over his clothes was his own, and the voice telling him he was a murderer was actually in his head.Kyle had reached breaking point and slashed his own skull with a knife in a bid to drown out the voice that had been terrorising him for months.One in ten people regularly hear voices that others dont as a result of illnesses like schizophrenia - a mental health condition which affects 220,000 people in the UK- and Kyle is one of them.After a messy break up and losing his job, Kyle tumbled into a bout of depression and began hearing a voice which told him he was worthless and should kill himself.Kyle first heard the voice ten months ago, and since then it has been constantly telling him to jump off buildings and cliffs.I was very, very lost and I think this is why the voice took hold so easily and took control, Kyle says on BBC3 documentary The Voices in My Head.He didnt tell anyone about the voice at first. Instead, he tried to block it out -  using music as a distraction.But after months of torment, Kyle resorted to trying to cut the sinister presence out of his head once and for all.In pure desperation, he took a blade and hacked into his skull just above his right ear - the point where it sounded like the voice was coming from.He passed out from blood loss. When he came to, the voice told him hed killed someone and Kyle believed it.Scared and confused, Kyle told a stranger that hed committed murder, and she called the police.Kyle then ran - fearing hed be locked up - and called his mum.When she found him, he had blood all over his face and had no choice but to confess everything about the voice.He was sent to a mental health ward, where he stayed for a month.Hes now using a combination of medication and therapy to get rid of the voice which has ruined his life - or at least quiet it down - and has a new job as a valet.In many cases, talking with therapists about the origins of voices can help to ease sufferers worries, and many can use the same coping mechanisms as people with anxiety to remain calm during intense episodes.But hell always bear the knife scar on his head, and for many people with schizophrenia, they must live their lives in the knowledge that the voices will never fully go away.Symptoms of schizophrenia can include having muddled thoughts, undergoing behavioural changes, and experiencing hallucinations and delusions.In some people, schizophrenic behaviours start suddenly, while they develop over time for others.Mental health charity Mind says: Some people think hearing voices means someone is dangerous, when voices are actually more likely to suggest that you harm yourself than someone else.Its also important to remember that people have a choice in whether they do what the voices say.The NHS says you should see your GP as soon as possible if you are experiencing the symptoms of schizophrenia.More information is available on the Mind website. Emmalina is sweeping the floor in her kitchen when shes interrupted by a sinister voice.Im going to kill you when you go outside, it says.Nobody else can hear it, but according to Emmalina, its the voice of the devil - a regular presence who torments her at her lowest moments and leaves her too scared to leave the house.Shes been hearing voices since she was eight and talking back to them for the past three years.As well as the devil, she lives with a voice called Katie - her closest friend - and the voice of her mother.Katie helped me get through really tough times when I was younger, Emmalina says.Emmalina endured sexual abuse and bullying in her childhood, and experts say that early trauma is often associated with hearing voices or developing multiple personalities.I wouldnt have got through childhood without Katie, Emmalina says. My life was unbearable.But Katie isnt always supportive of her.Emmalina says that in the past, Katies voice has told her to cut herself and to smash her own wrists with a hammer.The voice also routinely abuses her, calling her a fat b***h while she eats and even filling her head with racial slurs on the rare occasions when she ventures away from home.These days, Emmalina finds it difficult to leave the house at all, thanks to the increasingly frequent influences of the voice she attributes to the devil.Speaking in a sinister, upper-class accent, it routinely tells her that shell be killed if she steps outside.Im going to burn the skin off your bones, it says. Im going to drag you down to hell. Im going to get you.The voices threats have become so debilitating that Emmalina had to leave her job as a nursery assistant, and now relies on a support worker to try and control her condition.Schizophrenia is often misunderstood, and Australian TV show You Cant Ask That recently aired an episode where sufferers address misconceptions about the condition.Sufferers say that taking medication can suppress the voices, but at the height of their illnesses some reported hearing the voices of dead relatives, unborn children and - like Emmalina - the devil.Sandy can hear two voices, one male and one female.“They used to sound really crass in the way they spoke, but in the last 10 years they’ve done elocution, she says on the show.So now my voices abuse me with a posh accent.“They will tell me how evil I am, how disgusting I am, how disgusting I look, how my face is revolting, how if people touch me they will die because I will contaminate them with my oozing evil.”Other schizophrenic episodes have seen sufferers starve themselves - believing they were being told to by the Grim Reaper - and become convinced that theyre the target of government conspiracies.I have this lingering delusion in the back of my mind that Tony Blair has implanted a micro-chip in my left ear to delete my thoughts, Sandy adds.Fellow sufferer Steve adds: I hear voices all the time. Even just sitting here.“In the early days when I was unwell, if I didn’t do what the voices told me to do they would just get louder and louder and louder.For Chaz, the emergence of a voice which she calls Victor almost proved fatal.Victor has been an unwelcome fixture in Chaz life since 2013, but she was too scared of being sectioned to tell anyone about it.The voice heaps constant abuse on her, telling her that she has no right to be alive and that she can end the torment by killing herself.You should die, the voice says, during one particularly nasty outburst. Just die.After eight months of Victors constant goading, Chaz jumped from a bridge.I didnt want to hear it any more and I wanted everything to disappear, she says. I dont really remember being on the bridge.The police shouted my name. I turned towards them, turned back towards the bridge and just stepped off.Today, the former skateboarder is in a wheelchair as the result of the suicide attempt, which left her with a broken foot, two smashed wrists, a fractured pelvis and a fractured sternum.Chaz still hears Victors voice, and it sometimes even teases her about the day she almost died.I put you in a wheelchair, Victor says, and Chaz hears a foul-spirited laugh inside her head.Now, Chaz refuses to let Victor control her life. She writes and recites poetry about her condition to try and drown the voice out, and hopes to find love soon.I know its hard for anyone to be my friend, she says. But I do actually want to meet people. Id like a girlfriend.But its hard to get someone to stay around. Its terrifying to meet someone who doesnt necessarily want to live all day, every day.If you are struggling with suicidal thoughts or mental health issues, or someone you know is, call the Samaritans free of charge on 116 123 Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: british gran complained spanish benidorm hotel compensation
story: Freda Jackson, 81, demanded a refund for her Thomas Cook holiday after claiming she was left in tears because it was teeming with rude Spanish natives.The OAP from Blackburn, Lancs, had said: The hotel was full of Spanish holidaymakers and they really got on our nerves because they were just so rude.One evening a Spanish guy nearly knocked me flying and he just walked off without even apologising.The entertainment in the hotel was all focused and catered for the Spanish - why cant the Spanish go somewhere else for their holidays?However, her comments have sparked outrage in Spain, with thousands claiming it was a cynical ploy to cash in.Antonio Toni Mayor Suarez, President of the Benidorm Hoteliers Association, told The Sun Online: Surely this tourist was looking for their tour operator to return the money for their holiday, reflective of the culture of claim that we see, with some claims as inappropriate as the one described by this tourist.Eradicating the culture of claim among the British is something very difficult and something that should be done through cultural and educational context in the United Kingdom.Its legal system of claims has allowed these types of abuses to occur, the biggest example we suffered two years ago with the thousands of fraudulent claims for food poisoning that flooded Spanish hotels.It would be necessary to review the whole system of claims so that only those that are true and those that have involved damage are admitted.Scores of everyday Spaniards have also waded into the debate - echoing Antonios accusations.Martin Esteban said: I would like to remind Mrs. Jackson, that Benidorm is Spain, if she is not happy that she stays in her country, as well as the people of her country who come to get drunk.Rosa Humanes said: These English do not know what to do to have free vacations, adding that now the bargain of gastroenteritis has run out they make bulls*** new claims.Lucia Garcia Sanchez posted: You have to read between the lines. What she wants is for vacations to (be) free.The hotel itself said that Jackson had only made one complaint, and this was about the location of her room, which was changed at her request.Freda has since been offered compensation of £566 from Thomas Cook due to an error informing her about a change to her flights.A Thomas Cook spokesperson told The Sun Online: Due to a system error Ms Jackson was not informed of a change to her flights until six days before departure.We have offered Ms Jackson and her travel companion a gesture of goodwill to try and put things right which we hope she will accept.

title: womans lost contact lens lodged behind eye
story: The now 42-year-old assumed the contact lens had fallen out, but in fact it had moved behind her eye - yet didnt cause any symptoms for years.Then suddenly, six months before doctors discovered the lens, the unnamed woman started experiencing pain and swelling behind her eye.It appeared the size of a pea to start with, but still didnt causing any discomfort. Quickly it began to grow larger and became painful to touch.She was referred to an eye specialist at NHS Teeside by her GP, but the cause of the swelling remained a mystery.There was no scarring or inflammation on the upper eyelid, just a lump close to her nose.An MRI of the eye showed a cyst behind her left eye and she required surgery to remove it.It was during the surgery that doctors realised the cyst was a hard contact lens.But it still didnt explain where the contact lens had come from.Then her mother remembered that she was hit in the eye with a shuttlecock while playing badminton when she was 14.At the time she was wearing contact lenses but one of them wasnt found, so they assumed it fell out.She suffered swelling around the eye that eventually went down and she never wore hard contact lenses again.We can infer that the lens migrated into the patient’s left upper eyelid at the time of trauma and had been in situ for the last 28 years, Dr Sirjhun Patel wrote in the BMJ case report.The patient also had a droopy left eyelid, which doctors assumed was also caused by the rogue contact lens.Her vision was not damaged and she made a full recovery once the lens was removed.The migration of a rigid gas permeable (RGP) lens into the eyelid is a rare cause of eyelid swelling, Dr Patel added.Spontaneous migration of a hard contact lens into the eyelid is a relatively known occurrence, but we were only able to find four reported cases of lens migration secondary to significant trauma.This case report exhibits the longest time between traumatic RGP lens migration into the eyelid and presentation of eyelid swelling.

title: labour mp refuses six times to say jeremy corbyn is fit to be pm and hints he could be ousted as leader next month
story: Madeleine Moon failed six times when asked to say if the Labour leader was fit to become Prime Minister.She blasted him for dominating newspaper headlines with negative coverage over his controversial trip to Tunisia in 2014.He has admitted he laid a wreath to honour members of the Black September terrorists who killed 11 Israeli athletes at the Munich 1972 - but refused to apologise to the widows for attending.After pictures emerged of him at the ceremony at a cemetery in Tunis, Mr Corbyn initially denied he was involved - saying he was marking the deaths of 47 people in Israeli airstrikes in 1985.But he has since changed his story several times, and now faces a House of Commons probe over failing to properly declare the trip to the authorities.The Labour boss has come under increasing pressure this week, which comes on the back of the partys ongoing anti-Semitism crisis.And today Ms Moon, the MP for Bridgend, hinted that Mr Corbyn could face moves to oust him as early as Labour’s annual conference in Liverpool next month.She told TalkRadio: “Individuals as leaders come and go. And the party will look at this I am sure extremely forcefully at the next conference.Lets wait and see what conference decides.“Theres always a rule in politics: if youre on the front pages for too long you become the story and thats not good because you miss all the good and effective things that the Labour Party is doing in terms of policy and holding this government to account.”Host Julia Hartley-Brewer asked her: “Do you think that a man who lays wreaths at the tombs of terrorists who have killed innocent people is fit to be the British Prime Minister?”But Ms Moon would only reply: “That will be a decision for the British people.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
