title: couple unrecognisable after losing whopping
story: NewsCouple are unrecognisable after losing a whopping 12 STONE in less than a yearMatt and Naomi Opie from Plymouth say that they struggled with their weight after their son was diagnosed with ADHDShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMiles O'Leary11:03, 16 AUG 2018NewsThe pair joined their local Slimming World branch (Image: Matt Opie)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA husband and wife who once gorged on five takeaways a week have shed almost 12 STONE between them in just under a year. The transformation first came into fruition after Matt Opie, who topped the scales at nearly 16 stone, thought he was going to 'die' running after his son at their local park in Plymouth. Desperate to make a change to their lives, he and his partner Naomi, decided to head to their local Slimming World. Since they embarked on their weight-loss journey, the couple have said that their marriage has improved and has made them even better parents to their boy, Jack. It's been no easy feat and Matt was anxious at first about taking the plunge with so many other women around him aching to trim down.  Speaking to Plymouth Live , Matt said: When I first went, I walked in and there were 40 women in there, and perhaps two or three men, and I just thought, this isn't a man thing to do.   That's what people would think - but it's changed our lives. When I started, I was 15 stone, 11 pounds, Matt explained. I've managed to lose four stone - I had diabetes as well and that's gone. It's taken me 10 months. It sounds a bit funny, but we were laying in bed the other night and we were saying about all the extra room we've got now. We've lost more weight than what Naomi weighs now. You would think there were three of us in this bed. It's absolutely crazy. Naomi's journey is quite remarkable - she's shifted seven and a half stone and has not put on a single pound since she started weighing in at Slimming World last year. Matt reflected on what made him want to change his life.  My son has problems and we were seeing him at school, I was trying to get him but he was having a meltdown and I thought I was going to die having to try and run after him, he explained. As soon as that happened, I knew things had to change. My son has been diagnosed with ADHD - and now I can do more stuff with him. When he was going to the park and I was trying to run after him, I was out of breath. It may seem stupid to some people, but we are having more fun as a family now, doing more stuff together that we wouldn't do before like taking selfies. You should see the photos we had previously. Now, we're just taking selfies with everything. It feels like we're making up for lost time, Matt admitted.  We didn't really have family photos up before, now we're going to places like the zoo and taking lots of photos. Matt said the couple's weight climbed as problems got worse with their son. Struggling to get him to bed, they felt too exhausted to cook - and relied on their local takeouts to keep them going. But that only fed their weight problems - and made them feel exhausted and stressed. I was having four or five takeaways a week, sometimes twice a day, Matt said. Matt says - a diet full of salad and vegetables and swapping out chips for jacket potatoes. I eat salad and veg every day now, Matt said. Jacket potatoes - in my 37 years I had never eaten one until I started Slimming World and now I love jacket potatoes. We live on the third floor and we have a lift. For the last year, I've probably only used it three times. I would definitely advise any man to do Slimming World - it's changed my life. It changes every part of your life.

title: farmer puts 30ft wall hay
story: NewsFarmer puts 30ft-wall of hay outside neighbours' homes - but denies that he's a "bully"Residents have accused the farmer of "bullying" after the bales were heaped outside their homes in DerbyshireShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByArun Lal19:06, 15 AUG 2018NewsPeter Shaw, 55 and wife Helen, 50, are furious after the hay bales suddenly appeared (Image: SWNS)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA farmer has denied that he is a bully after 30ft-high stacks of hay were placed outside his wealthy neighbours' homes. The massive stack of hay has been piled up on trailers in a field adjacent to the back gardens of several &pound500,000 detached properties. Villagers believe they were put there deliberately after a planning application by farmer Richard Barton to run a waste processing site was rejected. But Mr Barton has defended the move, accusing neighbours of making a straw mountain out of a molehill. Among those affected was resident Peter Shaw, 55, who said the bales were stacked behind his house on Cole Road, Ockbrook, Derbyshire, last Thursday.  Mr Shaw and his wife Helen, 50, moved into the home in 2004, and say this is the first time they have encountered an issue with Mr Barton. Mr Shaw, who works in the motoring trade, says the bales are a potential fire risk and is urging Mr Barton, 44, to remove them. He said: The farmer won't speak to you, I have tried. He's just a bully. I truly believe it is just something we are going to have to live with now. I have contacted everyone and anyone that I possibly can and nothing seems to getting done about it.  It feels as though there is one rule for one person and another rule for others. It's an eye sore - I'm not sure they are even stored correctly. He's put 30 tons on a trailer. First, the lorries came and they were full of hay bales and he put them in place one by one. So we've got three in a row. More and more bales were put on top - there might be a row of seven or eight - I'm not entirely sure now. You can see it from the road, you can see it from the footbridge.  It's about ten meters from my home - if they were to fall then they would destroy my garden. I thought they were a fire risk but the fire brigade said to me they're not a fire risk. The farmer has been trying to put a planning application through now for the past eight years. He wants to create a site to process waste. The application has been rejected not just by ourselves but by the whole village. It just seems because my house backs onto his farm - that we have to bear the brunt of this. Another resident on the street said: The view from our back garden used to be open fields but now all you can see is a wall of hay.  I'm convinced this is some kind of protest against the village because the farmer didn't get the planning permission he wanted. It's a form of intimidation and is just simply being done out of spite. Speaking from his farm in Ockbrook, Derbys., where he lives with wife Samantha, 50, he said: It's got nothing to do with the planning application for a waste processing site. Where am I supposed to put my bales? They [the residents] are selfish - all they think about is themselves. All they want to see is green land but I don't even get that view and its my farm. I've got my property here, I can't put them [hay bales] on my drive because there's no space - I've got sheds in the way too. There's a dual carriageway on the other side I can't put them there. He added: They're making a straw mountain out of a molehill. I put them in the middle of the field and they complained about that and the council told me to move them. Now I've moved them they're complaining again. All they've done for the past few years is try and portray me as some horrible neighbour and horrible person. It's not their fields - I live literally next to the bales too. The fire brigade have come out and said it's not a fire risk. I don't know why they called me a bully - I'm not a bully. story: NewsGovernment worker 'bound and gagged to chair by sexist colleagues' LOSES bullying and harassment caseDeeAnn Fitzpatrick claimed a racist and misogynistic culture within her office drove her to contemplate suicideShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCharlie Gall06:41, 16 AUG 2018Updated07:30, 16 AUG 2018NewsDeeAnn Fitzpatrick says she was bound and gagged at work in 2010 (Image: BBC)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA government worker who claims she was tied to a chair and gagged by colleagues who bullied and harassed her has had her case thrown out. DeeAnn Fitzpatrick, 49, accused fellow fisheries workers of mocking and targeting her in a campaign of sexist harassment. The Canadian woman claimed a racist and misogynistic culture within the Marine Scotland office in Scrabster drove her to contemplate suicide. But an employment tribunal has rejected her claims despite a photo showing her gagged and taped to a chair appeared to back up her claims, the Daily Record reports. That evidence was time-barred.  In an earlier hearing in Aberdeen in June, Ms Fitzpatrick alleged she was taped to a chair and gagged by colleagues in 2010. The tribunal heard how she was bombarded with fake Valentine's Day and birthday cards she believed came from male colleagues A message in one called her an “old troll” and another warned her about trying to “climb the ladder of success”. Ms Fitzpatrick told the tribunal the harassment was so bad she considered taking her own life and contacted an assisted suicide clinic. She told the tribunal: “When I first started getting the cards, it made me feel awful. But as they continued, yes it’s affected my self-esteem. “It’s actually made me become a recluse - I stay at home, I have gone more into myself. With everything going on, I contacted Dignitas in Switzerland. I had enough.” Ms Fitzpatrick, who has worked for Marine Scotland since 2006, was struggling to grasp the tribunal’s verdict.  She said on Wednesday night: “It is difficult when you spend your entire career fighting racism, misogyny and bullies. “Then to make matters worse when you report the incidents, you are the one that is being targeted by an ongoing campaign by senior management because you exposed what they have worked very hard to hide.” The Scottish Government put up one witness, Judith MacKinnon, its head of people advice, who has over 25 years experience in human resources. MacKinnon took up the job last year but said those who dealt with Ms Fitzpatrick’s complaints were too scared to appear because of the intense media interest.  But she backed the decisions taken by junior staff who found insufficient evidence to back up Ms Fitzpatrick’s suspicions about the letters. However First Minister Nicola Sturgeon told MSPs she was “absolutely horrified” when shown the photo of Ms Fitzpatrick allegedly taped to a chair and gagged. She has ordered a top civil servant to conduct a full review into the circumstances and report to her personally. Ms Fitzpatrick’s sister-in-law Sherry said: “The Fitzpatrick family are hugely disappointed with the result of the tribunal.

story: NewsA-Level results: More than a QUARTER of all grades A or A* - the highest proportion for six yearsHundreds of thousands of students in England, Wales and Northern Ireland are receiving their A-level results today following major exam reformsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByIan JonesAlison KershawSophie Evans09:30, 16 AUG 2018Updated10:27, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMore than one in four A-levels were awarded an A or A* this year - the highest proportion for six years, national figures show. In total, 26.4 per cent of UK entries were given one of the two top grades, according to data published by the Joint Council for Qualifications (JCQ). This is up 0.1 percentage points on last year. However, figures also show that the proportion of A-Levels handed the very top result has fallen to its lowest level since 2013. One in 12 (8.0%) entries scored an A* grade this year, down 0.3 percentage points on 2017, statistics published by the council show.  The overall A*-E pass rate has also fallen 0.3 percentage points to 97.6%. This is the lowest level since 2010.   A Level results day 2018: All you need to know when you get your grades and what to do next  But the percentage of A-Levels awarded an A or A* is the highest since 2012, according to a Press Association analysis. It is the second year in a row that the A*-A pass rate has risen. Boys continue to outperform girls at the highest grades, the figures show. While 26.6% of boys' entries were awarded at least an A grade this year, this was the case for 26.2% of girls' entries. The statistics also show that STEM subjects (science, technology, engineering and maths) are continuing to rise in popularity. More than a third (36.2%) of all A-level entries were in these subjects, up from 34.5% last year, and 28% in 2009.  Male students are still more likely to study a STEM subject than females, but the balance is shifting, JCQ said. More girls take biology and chemistry than boys, while more boys take maths and physics. But the data also shows that girls are closing in on the boys, with a 3.1% increase in maths entries from female students (boys' entries for the subject have risen 2.1%) and a 6.9% rise in physics (2.4% for boys). More than half a million students in England, Wales and Northern Ireland are finding out their A-Level results today after an anxious wait. It comes in the wake of a major exams overhaul - with 24 A-level subjects now reformed. There has been a move away from coursework and modular exams, with sixth-formers instead sitting their exams at the end of two years of study. There have been major reforms to A-Level qualifications in England - with a move away from coursework and modular exams.  Instead, sixth formers sit their exams at the end of two years of study. A Department for Education spokeswoman said: We reformed A-levels after universities told us they were failing to prepare students for higher education. Reducing the number of exams students have to sit will give them more time for study and to gain a deeper understanding of the courses they are studying, an essential skill for undergraduate study. We know exam season can be a time of heightened emotions for pupils wanting to do their best but while testing has always been an important part of education, it should never be at the expense of a young person's wellbeing. That's why the Government is investing &pound1.7 billion to promote, protect and improve young people's mental health. Grades have been awarded for the first time this summer for new A-levels in languages, geography, dance, drama and theatre, music, PE and religious studies. They join the 13 A-level subjects for which the first grades were handed out last summer. Maths is in the process of being reformed and a small number of grades were handed out for the new qualification this summer. Most students have been awarded grades after studying the old A-level course. Overall, the subject is still the most popular A-level, with 2,383 more entries this year compared to 2017. Michael Turner, JCQ director general, said: Students, and teachers, should be congratulated. They can be confident in their grades, knowing they have been achieved in a world-class system that is robust, challenging and fair.  It comes as early figures have showed there has been a fall in the number of students accepted on degree courses at UK universities. In total, 411,860 students - from the UK and overseas - have taken up places, according to initial data published by admissions service Ucas. This is down 1% compared with the same point last year A breakdown shows 353,960 UK students have been accepted on to undergraduate courses, down 2% on 2017. But there is an increase in international students, with 26,400 EU applicants accepted to study at UK universities - up 1% on last year. And a record 31,510 students from nations outside the EU have taken up places - a 4% increase. The figures are a snapshot taken by Ucas shortly after midnight.    The admissions service said that in England, a record 27.9% of the 18-year-old population has been accepted on to courses, with a record 26.3% in Wales. In Northern Ireland, the entry rate is 28.1%, while in Scotland - where results were published last week - 25.9% of 18-year-olds have been accepted. Clare Marchant, Ucas chief executive, said an increase in the proportion of youngsters from disadvantaged background was excellent news. Some 16.1% of those from the most disadvantaged backgrounds have been accepted - up 0.4 percentage points. She added: However, the continuing gap between the most and least advantaged is frustrating, and we'll keep on working with universities to help them evaluate their outreach activities to impact the most disadvantaged students. The encouraging growth in international students choosing to study in the UK is testament to the welcome of our world-class universities. Students need to get around 55% of the answers right in their Biology A-level in order to secure an A grade, grade boundaries for one exam board suggest. The A grade pass mark required for the reformed OCR advanced Biology A-level is 54.8%, the figures on its website show. Those wanting an A in the reformed maths exam would need to get 65.6% of the answers right. Meanwhile, students who sat the English language A-level would be looking for 77% of the marks in order to secure an A. I'd advise anyone thinking about securing a place through clearing to take some time to visit universities and colleges in the next few days. This weekend's open days are listed on the Ucas website. Seeing everything in person can help you make the right decision. If you decide your next step isn't a degree though, information on apprenticeships, gap years and career options is also available on ucas. While many students hoping to go to a university or college of their choice will get the grades they need today, others will inevitably be left disappointed. But The Grand Tour presenter Jeremy Clarkson has told them not to worry. He tweeted: Don’t worry if your A level grades aren’t any good. I got a C and 2 Us. And I’m sitting here deciding which of my Range Rovers to use today. Earlier, Amanda Brown, deputy general secretary of the National Education Union, had argued that changes to A-Levels means that students are unable to fully demonstrate what they can do. Hundreds of thousands of teenagers have received their A-Levels today. Below, you can see the pass rate (students receiving A-E grades), broken down by nation and by region. Coursework and other non-exam assessments are a better way for students to demonstrate their skills, are less of a memory test, and help lower attaining students and those with special educational needs and disabilities show their achievements. But Education Secretary Damian Hinds said the redesign of the qualifications would make them more appropriate, better (at) preparing young people for moving on to the next stage, including university. He told Today: Having exams at the end of the two years means that it is possible to consider the subject as a whole, to bring in all the different parts of it, to synthesise the different aspects of the subject in a way that is a little closer to undergraduate study.  A Department for Education spokeswoman said: We reformed A-levels after universities told us they were failing to prepare students for higher education. This is the lowest level since 2013, when it was 7.6%.  - The overall pass rate (grades A-E) was 97.6%, down from 97.9% last year. This is the lowest pass rate since 2010, when it was also 97.6%. - Boys lead girls in the top grades for the second year running. The proportion of boys who got A or higher was 26.6%, 0.4 percentage points higher than girls (26.2%). - Last year, boys led girls by 0.5 percentage points (26.6% boys, 26.1% girls). story: NewsMan who 'had no control over his actions because of brain tumour' found guilty of killing great-niece with table legDelroy Forrester, 51, has been found guilty of manslaughter but not guilty of the murder of Jasmine Forrester, 11, hours after a hospital crisis team said it could not help himShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByElaine McCahill11:56, 16 AUG 2018Updated12:23, 16 AUG 2018NewsDelroy Forrester, 51, has been found guilty of killing his 11-year-old great niece (Image: Facebook)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who 'had no control over his actions because of brain tumour' has been found guilty of killing his 11-year-old great-niece with a table leg in a frenzied attack. Delroy Forrester was today found guilty of manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility but not guilty of her murder and will be sentenced on September 24.  Jasmine Forrester was battered to death with a table leg by her great-uncle who insisted the devil had to die after leaving her with near 100 injuries Forrester, 51, admitted killing the youngster hours after a hospital crisis team said it could not help him because he was not a risk, a jury heard. On Tuesday the court heard that Mr Forrester was suffering from a brain tumour. Wolverhampton Crown Court heard he had a tumour removed from his brain in 1999 but it had come back, reports the BBC.  Psychiatrist Dr Dinesh Maganty told the court that the tumour had taken over the rational part of his brain which meant he had no control over his actions. Dr Maganty said: Because the frontal lobe controls his inhibitions, he had a complete lack of control over his actions and emotions. There is clear evidence of a brain tumour. Clear evidence of epilepsy and psychosis. On Monday, the court heard how Forrester's daughter, Tyler Forrester, was angry her father was not in hospital and had called the crisis team at Penn Hospital in Wolverhampton hours before the incident to ask for help. The hospital is a major provider of mental health services.  After saying they could not assist her father, Ms Forrester said: You'd better make sure he doesn't kill my nan tonight. Jurors at Wolverhampton Crown Court were told that Forrester had in fact wanted to kill his son Myles, and was later heard speaking of Jasmine as being pure and innocent. The jury heard that a few days before the incident Forrester had been suffering from a psychotic mental disorder. Police had been called to the house of the defendant's mother and Jasmine's great-grandmother, Victoria Forrester, in Kent Road, Wolverhampton, in the early hours after the 79-year-old raised the alarm with her neighbour. Forrester, formerly of Lower Villiers Street in Blakenhall, denied murdering Jasmine on the basis he was legally insane at the time of the killing. Opening the case against Forrester on Monday, prosecutor Jonathan Rees QC said: In the early hours of Friday February 9 2018, Jasmine was the subject of a frenzied and sustained attack by the defendant, in the course of which he used a broken table leg to inflict... catastrophic head injuries. The defendant does not dispute that he killed Jasmine in the way alleged.  However, he has pleaded not guilty to the allegation of murder on the basis that he was, in the legal sense, insane at the time he assaulted her and inflicted the fatal head injuries. Mr Rees continued: (Tyler) Forrester was angry that her father had not been taken to hospital and so she contacted the Crisis Team at Penn Hospital at 9.13pm (on February 8). They asked her if her father was at risk and she said 'No'. They indicated that in those circumstances there was nothing they could do, in response to which she said in anger 'You'd better make sure he doesn't kill my nan tonight'. Speaking of Forrester's actions after the attack, Mr Rees said: While the defendant was being held (by officers) outside, he started singing phrases such as 'You are the Lord my God...'. An officer asked whether the child was safe and the defendant responded by singing that the child wasn't safe and he was a bad man.  He added that 'the devil had to die, I kill her blud' and 'the devil is dead'. Speaking of how Forrester felt after the incident, Mr Rees said: He stated he felt devastated by what he had done to Jasmine. He spoke of her being pure and innocent, and said that his son, Myles, had tricked him into thinking that Jasmine was the devil whereas, in fact, Myles was the devil. Giovanni D’Alessandro from the CPS said: “Jasmine was a friendly, caring and well-liked girl who had a bright future ahead of her. This was all taken away by Delroy Forrester.

story: NewsWhy Prince Charles might not become King Charles when he takes the throneThe Queen's former spokesman revealed that Prince Charles will inherit a host of royal titles when he becomes KingShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNeil MurphyCourtney PochinAudience Writer02:59, 16 AUG 2018Updated03:13, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Charles may not become King Charles when he takes the throne, it has been revealed. The Prince of Wales may change his name when he becomes monarch, according to Queen's former spokesman Dickie Arbiter. The first-in-line to the throne may instead change his official title to one of his middle names - a royal tradition that dates back generations. “He might choose one of his other names Philip, Arthur or George”, Arbiter told HELLO! magazine. Monarchs often assume new titles when they they become King or Queen, including the Queen's father King George VI. George VI was baptised Albert Frederick Arthur George - after his great-grandfather Prince Albert - and was called Bertie by those closest to him. King Edward VII’s Christian name was also Albert.  King Edward VIII used his original name but used his final middle name David with close friends and family Arbiter also revealed that Charles will inherit a host of royal titles when he takes the throne, including Duke of Lancaster, Defender of the Faith, Supreme Governor of the Church of England, Head of the Commonwealth, and King of other Realms and Territories.  He told Hello Magazine : Charles will also be Lord of the Man (Isle of Man) and Duke of Normandy.  “But generally he'll only be known as King.  Wills and Kate may also change their titles when Charles becomes king. Currently known as the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, the happy couple, both 36, could also gain two other royal titles. According to royal expert Marlene Koenig, the pair might inherit Charles' titles once he takes the throne. Speaking to HELLO! Magazine Marlene explained that while William will always be HRH Duke of Cambridge, he may end up being styled as HRH The Duke of Cornwall and Cambridge.

title: princess diana secret second wedding
story: NewsPrincess Diana had a secret second wedding dress - and she didn't even know about itPrincess Diana's wedding dress is an iconic piece of fashion history, but she could have walked down the aisle wearing something else entirelyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer09:47, 16 AUG 2018NewsDiana could have worn a different dress down the aisle (Image: PA)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Before Harry and Meghan and William and Kate, there was the grand royal wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer.   The pair officially tied the knot on July 29 1981 at St Paul's Cathedral and the world watched the fairytale ceremony in awe.   Diana's look for her big day is one that has gone down in fashion history, with her large princess dress made of ivory silk taffeta inspiring brides across the planet.  But it's recently been revealed that the 20-year-old princess-to-be could have walked down the aisle in a very different outfit.   According to People , the designers of her wedding gown, David and Elizabeth Emanuel , had made a second wedding dress for Diana - and it was kept so heavily under wraps that even the bride didn't know it existed.  A lot of effort went in to keeping the dress out of the public eye before the big day, with the designers even going as far as to destroy their sketches straight after they'd been shown to Diana. But in case the design for the original were to be leaked, another dress was created as a back-up option. At the time we wanted to make absolutely sure that the dress was a surprise, said David.  We didn’t try it on Diana. We never even discussed it. We wanted to make sure that we had something there it was for our own peace of mind, really. So Diana never even saw the second dress which was made from the same fabric as the first and also featured ruffles around the neck. However there were a few big differences between the two. The secret dress was a lot less lavish than the original version, lacking the antique lace and 10,000 mother-of-pearl sequins as well as the 25-foot train.

story: NewsRoyals' A-levels: Here's how Prince Harry, Meghan Markle, Prince William and Kate Middleton did at schoolWhile some of the royal family did as well as you may think others achieved just a handful of qualifications - and one achieved noneShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRachel Bishop10:37, 16 AUG 2018Updated12:20, 16 AUG 2018News (Image: Tim Graham Photo Library)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWith private educations and millions of pounds behind them you'd expect the royals to do pretty well at school. But while some did as well as you may think, others achieved just a handful of qualifications - and one particularly high profile royal achieved none. Despite having what has been described as an aptitude for learning, The Queen didn't have time for formal schooling, having to instead learn the constitutional monarchy ropes from a young age. In contrast, her children and grandchildren have enjoyed a more normal education - and varying degrees of success to show for it.   So how do the royals qualifications measure up? Prince William From 1990, William attended Ludgrove School in Berkshire for five years until he started at Eton College in 1995 where he took his GCSEs and A Levels. He left Eton in 2000 achieving an A in Geography B Art and C Biology. Like many students, The Duke of Cambridge chose to have a gap year before beginning his university course in order to travel and gain a variety of new experiences. He went on to gain a 2:1 degree in Geography at St Andrews University in Scotland, which is where he met his wife.  The Duchess of Cambridge Kate achieved 11 GCSEs at St. Andrew’s School in Pangbourne in 1995 and then went on to Marlborough College in Wiltshire, where she achieved As in Maths and Art, and a B in English. Leaving Marlborough College in July 2000, The Duchess of Cambridge undertook a gap year in which she studied at the British Institute in Florence, undertook a Raleigh International programme in Chile, and crewed on Round the World Challenge boats in the Solent. Kate graduated from St Andrews University in 2005 with a 2:1 in History of Art  Prince Harry Probably one of the least academic achievers is Prince Harry, who studied at Eton, gaining 11 GCSE's and a B in Art and D in Geography in his A Levels. On the royal's website it simply says: His Royal Highness went on to Eton College from September 1998 where he took his GCSEs and A Levels. On William's it outlines the three A Levels he took. Harry had plenty of successes though throughout his education and during his time at Eton, he was House Captain of Games and represented the school at rugby, cricket and polo, and was a member of the Combined Cadet Force.  He left in 2003 and joined the Army, but before doing so, he spent a year travelling to Australia, Argentina and Africa, where he made a documentary about the plight of orphans in Lesotho. The Duchess of Sussex, Meghan Markle Meghan began her secondary education at Immaculate Heart High School in 1992 where she was known as a hard working and focused student. During her high school years, The Duchess of Sussex performed in theatrical productions at both Immaculate Heart and Loyola High School. Her former drama teacher, Gigi Perreau, who directed Meghan in seven plays, remembered that her former student sparkled.  She said: You see someone nice to the other kids, who gets good grades, doesn't say anything bad about anybody. America does not test students using GCSEs or A Levels, and it is has not been reported what Meghan got on her SATs (which is the test students take as an entry into university) but it is known that she got the grades she needed to get into university. She went on gain a double major in Theatre and International Relations at Northwestern University in Evanston, Illinois in 2003. During her time at university, The Duchess completed an internship at the US Embassy in Buenos Aires, Argentina, where she learned to speak Spanish. She also studied French for six years.  The Queen She's met politicians and film stars, speaks French fluently, loves to colour block and still rides a horse at 91 years of age, but the Queen has never sat an academic exam in her life meaning she hasn't a single GCSE or A Level (O Levels back then) to In her early childhood, the Queen was taught by a governess from 9.30am until 11am. Following the abdication of her uncle Edward VIII in 1938, Elizabeth needed to prepare herself for her future role and received lessons on constitutional history from the vice provost of Eton, Henry Marten. The Queen’s father had disliked school and her mother thought it was more important to have fun,’ Professor Kate Williams, author of Young Elizabeth told Good Housekeeping . Unlike her father, the Queen was and is very bright and had an appetite for learning as well as a razor sharp memory. The lack of a formal education didn't harm her as she's naturally analytical and something of an autodidact, as well as being hard working - which we know now is just as important as raw brainpower.    Prince Charles Prince Charles was educated at Gordonstoun where he achieved five O-levels (GCSEs) and two A-levels - a B in History and a C in French C. He then went on to Cambridge University where he achieved a 2:2 degree in History Legend has it his bodyguard who was present at all lectures with the young prince sat the exams too - and got a First. Princes Diana Princess Diana met with less success and failed all her O-levels, twice. However she apparently excelled in deportment, having attended finishing school in Switzerland.  Princess Anne, Prince Andrew and Prince Edward Princess Anne, the Princess Royal, attended Benenden school in Kent where she gained six O-levels, and three A-levels in English, History and Politics. While Prince Andrew attended Gordonstoun like his older brother, his academic choices were much like Anne's - six O-levels and A-levels in English, History and Politics. Perhaps unsurprisingly, Prince Edward also went to Gordonstoun and has nine O-levels, three A-levels in English, History and Politics. He then gained a 2:2 degree in History from Cambridge University.

title: teenage lottery winner callie rogers
story: NewsTeenage lottery winner Callie Rogers dragged around by two women 'like a rag doll' after boozy night outMarie Hinde and Jade Quayle both face jail after admitting assaulting Callie Rogers - who scooped £1.86m aged just 16Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter07:50, 16 AUG 2018NewsThe court heard that Callie Rogers told the taxidriver she was 'the girl that won the lottery' (Image: Callie Rogers/Instagram)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of the UK's youngest ever lottery winners was attacked by two women after a night out, a court heard. Callie Rogers was kicked, punched and dragged her around 'like a rag doll' by Marie Hinde, 37, and Jade Quayle, 26, who have admitted assault. The pair, both dogsitters, now face jail for their attack on the 31-year-old, who scooped &pound1.8 million when she was just 16.  They dragged the mum around a living room “like a rag doll” and left her bloodied and needing hospital treatment, according to reports.  Callie recently admitted she has struggled with the fame her huge win brought her back in 2003 when she won the big prize. She revealed how she blew her jackpot on drugs, partying and boob jobs. Much of her fortune went on &pound18,000 for boob jobs, &pound250,000 on cocaine, another &pound300,000 on clothes and she gave away &pound500,000 to friends and family. Callie previously said: At 16 you're just a child, then suddenly overnight you've got to become an adult.  You don't have any understanding of money and the concept of what it brings, she continued.  There were people who came along who I did not know before and have not been in my life since. At the time, you just want everybody to like you. The money did bring problems with my family, and friends as well. It just became too much to cope with. On the night of the attack, in July last year, she was in a taxi heading to her then-boyfriend's.

title: uk weather forecast summer heatwave
story: NewsUK weather forecast heatwave: Summer to return with temperatures soaring above 30CCooler weather brought a welcome break from extreme heat that lasted weeks, but stifling temperatures are on the way backShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBrett Gibbons08:02, 16 AUG 2018Updated08:31, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA heatwave that baked Britain for weeks could be on its way back with temperatures that could soar past 30C before summer's end. Warm and humid conditions are expected in parts of the country after days of cloudy and rainy weather brought a welcome break from extreme heat. Temperatures peaked at 35.3C in Faversham, Kent on July 26 as summer heat records fell across the country. Hot weather is set to return to the UK in the coming days and it could carry on into September, according to forecasts.  Until then, parts of Britain will see some miserable weather. Parts of northwest England and Scotland are braced for heavy downpours with up to 30mm of rain expected in some locations before the end of this week. But the chance of pressure building next week could bring a return to more pleasant, settled weather.    However, there is still a risk of showers or longer spells of rain further north - despite the improving picture. Fresh breezes are possible while the rain continues but there will be some respite, with occasional brighter and drier intervals likely, especially as the weekend progresses. In the south and east more dry weather will bring mainly brighter, sometimes sunny, periods. This could create some warm and humid conditions especially when the sun shines.

title: womans open letter snobs who
story: NewsWoman's amazing open letter to snobs who look down on care workers: "We don't just wipe bums"Beth Sturgis, 24, from Plymouth, has been a carer for four years and took to social media to set the record straightShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKatie Timms10:27, 16 AUG 2018Updated10:55, 16 AUG 2018NewsBeth says nothing grips me more than when naivety leads people to believe all she does is wipe bums (Image: Beth Sturgis / SWNS)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A woman has written an open letter to people who look down on carers and says they are not glorified a** wipers.  Beth Sturgis, 24, has been a carer for almost four years and says nothing gripes her more than when naivety leads people to believe all she does is wipe bums. Now Beth, from Plymouth, Devon, has written a letter to any nay-sayers and shared it online. The post has since gone viral, and Beth said she is overwhelmed and shocked with the reaction to her post, with around 5,000 views.  She wrote: Today I was a cleaner, a cook, a hand to hold, a friendly face, a washer, a dresser, a helper, a CARER today I was human. Today I helped a man that has lived through the war wash and dress because old age has now hit him and he is unable to walk or do these things for himself. His body is ageing faster than his mind, but he is still so positive and always has a smile on his face. Today I helped a lady who this time last year was living her life normally to complete her normal daily tasks. Because she is now living her life with a cruel disease that has taken over her body and left her unable to do these things for herself, and has confined her to a wheelchair. I saw the pain in her eyes, the 'why me?', the frustration behind her smile and her braveness and will to live through this. Today I administered medication to a lady living life with Alzheimer’s, medication that she doesn’t even know why she’s taking it.  Medication that I know and that she knows will not prevent the inevitable. Medication that will not prevent the fact that one day she may go from not remembering where she put something, to not remembering who her own family are. Medication that will not cure this horrible disease because one has not been found yet and it may never be found. Today I saw the fear in her eyes. Beth, who works for Bluebird Care, says that her job is in no way easy and that she becomes attached to those she cares for. I have attended funerals of those I have helped. Those who I have seen twice maybe even four times a day and I have cried at the loss of those lives Beth said. The impact that has on me is sometimes as sad as the loss of my own family, because it is hard to not become attached. There are days I come home and cry because of things I have to deal with, things that I cannot control and things that I cannot wave a magic wand and cure. But I do this job because I care. Nothing grips me more than when someone’s refers to careworkers as “glorified ass wipers” or their naivety leads them to believe that that is all we do. Yes I wipe asses, yes I deal with stuff that not everyone would want to but that is not all I do. Today I helped a man that has lived through the war wash and dress because old age has now hit him and he is unable to walk or do these things for himself because his body is ageing faster than his mind, but he is still so positive and always has a smile on his face. Today I helped a lady who this time last year was living her life normally to complete her normal daily tasks because she is now living her life with a cruel disease that has taken over her body and left her unable to do these things for herself and has confined her to a wheelchair. I saw the pain in her eyes, the “why me?”, the frustration behind her smile and her braveness and will to live through this. Today I administered medication to a lady living life with Alzheimer’s. Medication that she doesn’t even know why she’s taking it, medication that I know and that she knows will not prevent the inevitable, medication that will not prevent the fact that one day she may go from not remembering where she put something, to not remembering who her own family are. Medication that will not cure this horrible disease because one has not been found yet and it may NEVER be found. Today I saw the fear in her eyes. Today I was a cleaner, a cook, a hand to hold, a friendly face, a washer, a dresser, a helper, a CARER  today I was human. I get paid less an hour than someone who stacks shelves in a supermarket, does this annoy me? Yes. Would I go stack shelves? No. Because nothing beats the smile I put on someone’s face, the satisfaction you get from making a small difference to someone’s life, to help them live their lives as independently as they can, the feeling of purpose. No my job is not easy, there are days I come home and cry because of things I have to deal with, things that I cannot control and things that I cannot wave a magic wand and cure, and believe me I have a lot of those moments where I pray I could. I have hard days but I also have amazing days. I have attended funerals of those I have helped, those who I have seen twice maybe even four times a day and I have cried at the loss of those lives. The impact that has on me is sometimes as sad as the loss of my own family, because it is hard to not become attached. But I do this job because I CARE. So yes I may wipe asses, but that is not all I do. I am proud to be a carer and to work in this industry. So next time you think that that is all a being a Care worker means please think again. No I do not save lives, but I sure as hell make them easier for someone to live. To all you carers out there, I salute you. They may not remember my name but they will remember what difference I made to their lives and I will go to my grave knowing I did a job that helped others! EDIT: I am overwhelmed and shocked with the amount of likes, comments and shares my post has received. To all of you who have commented and shared I am sorry I haven’t been able to respond to each and everyone of you personally. Thank you for your lovely comments and thank you again to each and everyone of the carers out there for all you do. You make the world a better place!!! Remember that each and everyone of you make a difference in this world including those of you who work in a supermarket, no offence is meant here just a comparison in wages and area of work. To those considering a role in the care industry I promise you you won’t regret it!! — feeling proud with Bluebird Care - South Hams, Torbay &amp Plymouth

story: NewsWaitress serves up beers completely naked - and customers' reactions are absolutely brilliantShannon decided against the bar's normal uniform, and decided to go for her own unique look insteadShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor07:49, 16 AUG 2018Updated10:15, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen customers at Lee's Landing Docking Bar in Maryland popped in for a cheeky afternoon drink, they were just expecting a nice relaxing afternoon and a few laughs with their pals. title: teenager 19 caught cctv trying
story: NewsMan tries to throw 14-year-old girlfriend in front of oncoming train in horrifying CCTVLucas Gary Narkle dragged his girlfriend toward the oncoming train as she struggled to avoid being hurled onto tracksShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter08:59, 16 AUG 2018Updated09:15, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenager tried to throw his girlfriend, five years his junior, in front of a train in horrifying CCTV footage. Lucas Gary Narkle dragged his girlfriend toward the oncoming train as she struggled to avoid being hurled onto the tracks at Elizabeth South station in Adelaide in October last year. The shocking incident was caught on camera at the station. Narkle, 19, faced the South Australian District Court on Wednesday, after earlier pleading guilty to endangering the girl's life. She was just 14 years old at the time.  The court heard Narkle's girlfriend was holding on for dear life as she was being dragged by him. She wasn't to know that he was going to stop, a prosecutor said regarding the incident. Narkle was originally charged with attempted murder and at the time was armed with a baseball bat, although both sides agreed it was not used. The 19-year-old was taken into custody following the incident and spent more than three months in prison until he was granted bail by the Supreme Court in February. Judge Simon Stretton said on Wednesday he was unlikely to impose further jail time on Narkle.  I have to bear in mind that his actual actions here are brief, irresponsible and didn't cause any physical harm at all, he said. I think nothing is going to be served by imposing a further term of actual imprisonment but I am strongly inclined towards an extended community service work. Narkle arrived more than 30 minutes late for the hearing, blaming public transport issues for the delay, reports Australian media. “Shout out to my boys in Yatala (Labour Prison),” was his only comment to reporters outside court. Narkle will return to court for sentencing on Thursday.

title: 200k improvements to dundee parks set to be approved
story: Dundee councillors are to be asked next week to approve spending more than £200,000 on a range of environmental improvements.Work is to be carried out at Balgay totalling £137,500.Elaine Zwirlein, director of neighbourhood services, said: “Work here includes the redesign and landscape improvements to include stabilisation of walls and installation of an overspill car park.“There will also be improvements to steps and additional tree planting. Friends of Balgay have been consulted regarding this.”Another £50,000 is to be spent carrying out improvements to seven playgrounds throughout the city.Ms Zwirlein said: “Works mainly include resurfacing and installation of wood chips, along with enhancing some of the equipment.“A further £29,500 is to be spent renewing fencing at Downfield Park and building a new gate.”
